reviewText: Recommended Sniping Game
Great single player game. Had a lot of fun with it, but it probably has the worst multiplayer ever.

TL;DR;  :  If you're looking for a great sniper game... Get Sniper Elite 2 or 3 instead of this.  But it's worth it if you get it on sale.

I tried really hard to like this, but after playing Sniper Elite 2 and 3, this just doesn't come anywhere close.  I think if I'd played this first, I would have enjoyed it a lot more because it's a decent game in it's own right.

But things is does terribly wrong:

* Single player campaign is too short.  I finished it in under 6 hours.  (I positive I've spent more time on a single level in Sniper Elite 3!)
* It's too scripted.  Try to leave the mission area, or complete a task in any way other than directed, and you alert all the troops.
* There's no thought involved. Just follow your AI spotter and shoot the enemies in the order that he tags them.

I'm going to play through once more on highest difficulty and see if it's more enjoyable.  There's also a DLC pack which promises to be more open and less scripted, which also has better reviews, so I'll try that at some point too. (Siberian Strike)

The game looks, plays, and feels like Call of Duty, except the only weapon you get to use is a sniper rifle. There are several different kinds of sniper rifles (MSR, M24, M82A1, etc.), but the only other weapon you have to use is a suppressed pistol, firing which feels like shooting a BB gun. The voice acting is horribly bad, and I do mean BAD. The game is almost played for you unless you are playing on the hardest difficulty. Everything is spelled out for you almost exactly, including where to go, who to kill and in what order, and where every last enemy is. On that note, enemies are lifeless. You might as well be shooting at mannequins. They will randomly spew out different phrases in Russian(?), from, I believe, a pool of set quotes. This being an FPS I'm not too surprised. The game also 'borrows' tricks and gimmicks from Call of Duty 4 rather frequently... I won't give any spoilers though.

Despite all this, environments are verdant and, though linear, well-designed as far as visuals go. The sniper aspect is, though somewhat inaccurate, challenging enough; firing a shot at the wrong time will have several automatic rifles firing in your direction, a bit pulse-pounding, but this is easily avoided, because, even though bullets can fly straight through enemies and hit a piece of metal behind them, resulting in a loud 'pang' sound, this will still not alert them. In fact I'm sure the only way to get detected is to stand in their direct line of sight, and even then it takes a few seconds for them to notice you. It's also apparent that you are playing as a perfectly weightless man, because you cannot hear your footsteps at all - I'm serious, they are completely silent. Because of this, you can sprint up behing an enemy and stab him with no difficulty at all.

Definitely one of my less enjoyed shooters, but at least the sniping is a bit (and I do mean a VERY SMALL BIT) more realistic than Call of Duty.

I bought this game primarily for the single player, with multiplayer being secondary.

The single player was interesting, giving you a variety of options for dealing with a varying number of enemies in different scenarios.  Whether it be the sniper bullet blowing up a hand grenade on an enemy's belt, or just a good ol' fashioned melee from behind, you have to choose not only your manner of killing, but the timing, very carefully.  After playing through most of the campaign once on Normal, I can definitely see the replay value for this game on hard, or just for fun on easy.

Multiplayer wise I only needed a few matches to see what this game is.  Sniping, camping, and painfully slow-paced.  It's a sniper game where you only get snipers essentially... if you've played enough CoD or Battlefield, you know exactly what that means.

All in all, if you want this game for the campaign/single player content, definitely worth a few playthroughs.  If you're looking for an obscure multiplayer FPS for some reason.... keep looking.  Fortunately, I bought this for the former of those two, and was not disappointed.

If you are into sniping game, this is a very fun sniping game. Multiplayer is a bit hard and requires practice.

Short, uninspiring, forgettable, easy.

Any difficulty aside from hard tells you exactly where to aim, effectively bypassing its own sniping mechanics with what amounts to a secondary reticle.  This makes hard difficulty the only possible way to have the long range sniping experience.  But then, even on hard the AI is too dumb to deal with you, just shoots accurately.  Follow your spotters instructions when in combat and watch as the AI clears your path for you during the mandatory stealth sections.  Things can go wrong and devolve into a shoot-out, but since everything dies in one shot to the torso, finesse is basically optional.  This is not a game designed to challenge your playing abilities, merely to challenge your ability to do exactly what you're told at exactly the right time.

A story exists, but it is not memorable and serves more as a crutch to carry you through the missions on rails while your spotter is there to hold your hand and make sure you don't do anything like make your own decisions.  A personal grievance I had was the game stressing the importance of stealth during two sections that made you rely on only your pistol and a few rounds of bullets while you pretend the guy you just knifed was not carrying a gun.  Not a gamebreaker, because you don't encounter more targets than you have ammo during these sections and they can all be taken out with a knife.  But it is a testament to lazy storytelling, trying to instill a sensation that simply does not run parallel to what the game is having you do.

Looks pretty though.  But what Cryengine game doesn't.

This game has many enjoyable aspects to it, such as the pretty great feeling when sniping, the good- looking graphics and the amazing killcams over 1000 meters.

However - the singleplayer campaign was one of the worst campaigns in video game history that I have ever played.

The whole thing felt extremely forced upon you - no way to do anything by yourself. Literally every stealth kill you take is dictated. While I generally enjoy linear games for their great attention to detail and often great storytelling, this game has neither of these aspects, but still is one of the most linear shooters I have ever seen, leading to a rather boring experience that makes you feel like the clown in a theater play.

The story is uninspired - I didn't care at all about any of the NPCs in the game, at any point - I probably couldn't name any name from the campaign right now. The voice acting however is pretty solid, but nothing special. The characters did not evolve in any real way, I could pretty much tell from the beginning what they were going to act like.

The mechanics in the SP campaign are standard- esque. I enjoy the fact that the game does not have regenerating health, and requires you to at least somewhat care about medpacks. You actually die from very few shots, even on easier difficulities. The stealth mechanic however felt a little awkward for me at times - you could literally play peek-a-bo with a wall of enemies from behind a ledge, and none of the enemies would even blink. What's missing here is a visible curiousity" state in between unaware and spotted

recommended: all in all - if you're for some quick sniper action without any real depth

The original Sniper: Ghost Warrior game was terrible. You can argue that all you want but having played it myself and not gotten a refund, I won't listen. The shooting mechanics offer some variety on the higher difficulty settings but overall the lack of challenging shots leaves a lot to be desired. The positioning aspect of the game amounts to walking along a predetermined path to painfully obvious hides. You take out a few waves of enemies with your high powered rifle. You move on to the next level.

While this is no-punches-pulled for what the game advertises, I find it hard to justify the price when a much more competent competitor lets you enjoy shooting Hitler between the legs. If you want a ballistics simulation get either Sniper Elite v2 or Arma 3.

If you want that Pripyat level of Call of Duty for an entire game, look no further.

The game looks, plays, and feels like Call of Duty, except the only weapon you get to use is a sniper rifle. There are several different kinds of sniper rifles (MSR, M24, M82A1, etc.), but the only other weapon you have to use is a suppressed pistol, firing which feels like shooting a BB gun. The voice acting is horribly bad, and I do mean BAD. The game is almost played for you unless you are playing on the hardest difficulty. Everything is spelled out for you almost exactly, including where to go, who to kill and in what order, and where every last enemy is. On that note, enemies are lifeless. You might as well be shooting at mannequins. They will randomly spew out different phrases in Russian(?), from, I believe, a pool of set quotes. This being an FPS I'm not too surprised. The game also 'borrows' tricks and gimmicks from Call of Duty 4 rather frequently... I won't give any spoilers though.

Despite all this, environments are verdant and, though linear, well-designed as far as visuals go. The sniper aspect is, though somewhat inaccurate, challenging enough; firing a shot at the wrong time will have several automatic rifles firing in your direction, a bit pulse-pounding, but this is easily avoided, because, even though bullets can fly straight through enemies and hit a piece of metal behind them, resulting in a loud 'pang' sound, this will still not alert them. In fact I'm sure the only way to get detected is to stand in their direct line of sight, and even then it takes a few seconds for them to notice you. It's also apparent that you are playing as a perfectly weightless man, because you cannot hear your footsteps at all - I'm serious, they are completely silent. Because of this, you can sprint up behing an enemy and stab him with no difficulty at all.

Definitely one of my less enjoyed shooters, but at least the sniping is a bit (and I do mean a VERY SMALL BIT) more realistic than Call of Duty.

I also tried some multiplayer but that was just too lame.
I don't blame the lameness on the developers though, but on the community.
Most of the people just wanted to spawn, find a good spot and then lie there staring at the building with the enemies on the other side of the map until they eventually spotted an enemey and fired or got fired upon and died without noticing where it came from.
To add another dimension to this, and perhaps to counter this kind of boring gameplay, the developers have added the possibility to cross an open field and get to the enemies house on the other side.
That was a good thing i thought. That would add a risk of camping and just staring down a scope, or hiding too well so you cant get a good overview - for ex to spot an enemy crossing.

reviewText: 10min of play. The avatar they chose shakes like an old arthritic starteled grandma. I can shoot better than this guy and I'm almost blind. All the mobs are closed in small areas so once you pick a target start shooting fast you just agroed the whole map. Chances are you won't get past the first level of this. No time to learn what the game wants from you. No clue to how far away do the mobs have to be from each other not to be aggroed. No chance to see the map area to plan a stratagy. You die as soon as you move after the cut seen pushes you into view of the enemy. All that is playable is the target range. The actions respoce times are very slow.\nI don't know why they did this but I have all the audio maxed out on every setting and it's still so quiet I can not hear the instructions the team mate is giving. I'm starting to notice a trend with CI games.  They always seem to have some pretty good graphics but they always tend to go corny on the story.  Sniper 2 was quite a bit better than the previous ghost warrior or in other words, I  liked this one.  All the environments are really well done and you could actually pick people off without alerting the whole map every time(unlike the original where as soon as you shot somebody the entire map knew where you were and would come after you full force) .

The good:


Very nice graphics
Interesting locations
Better gameplay than previous game


The bad:


Story was corny, but I kind of expected that



Overall it was a pretty good game.  I wouldn't buy it full price but on a sale it's a good 6 hours of fun
